author: Special Correspondent
text:
The beating of traditional ‘thandora’ dominated the proceedings at the farmers’ grievances day meeting.

The farmers, who complained that the assessment of crop damage during the recent heavy downpour was not done in a foolproof manner, said that they were not informed properly about the visit of the assessment teams in advance.

Usually, the officials used to inform the villagers on the visit of such teams by beating the ‘thandora’. But such practice was not adopted in any of the villages, alleged Thiagarajan of Arasanatham. At least in future, this practice should be adopted, he said.

A minor clash ensued between the participating farmers over the issue as a section objected to airing grievances which had no connection with the farmers.

N. Perumal, president, Salem District Vivasaya Sangam, said that the officials should ensure that only the real issues concerning the farmers alone be allowed to be raised in such meetings.

He threatened to stage a walkout from the future meetings, if people were allowed to raise issues which had nothing to do with farmers.

Some of the farmers’ representatives took exception to Mr. Perumal’s statement and said that there was nothing wrong in raising the issues confronting the rural people.
title: Clash over matter raised at meeting
